What if you could get a notification every time someone opened your resume?
No more wondering. No more guessing. Just actual signals.

A few months ago, I was deep in the job hunt hustle. I reached out like crazy to managers, HRs, talent acquisition teams, alumni, friends-of-friends... you name it. Sent out dozens of resumes every single day.

But here's the thing ğŸ¤”:
I had no idea who actually opened them. No idea who was just ghosting me,
and who mightâ€™ve actually taken a look.
Thatâ€™s when I built Visly ğŸ‘€.

ğŸ”ğ–ğ¡ğšğ­ ğ¢ğ¬ ğ•ğ¢ğ¬ğ¥ğ²?
Visly is a Chrome Extension that shows you who checked out your resume and when. So you can follow up with the people who actually showed interest. No more guessing. No more hoping someone might have seen it.

âš™ï¸ ğ‡ğ¨ğ° ğ¢ğ­ ğ°ğ¨ğ«ğ¤ğ¬ :
1ï¸âƒ£ Highlight someoneâ€™s name (e.g. on LinkedIn)
2ï¸âƒ£ Click the â€œğŸ“ Copy Linkâ€ button (a unique, trackable resume link is copied)
3ï¸âƒ£ Send the link and get notified when they view your resume (name + date + time)

Itâ€™s lightweight, free, and built to make job hunting a little less blind. ğŸ‘€
ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» Check it out here:
ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dJ5-FG9K

Do give it a try and tell me how it goes ğŸš€

My best friend just left Google </3

17th April 2024: It was my 3rd day at Google when I met Divyam. My first impression of him was that of a quiet, shy guy whoâ€™d keep to himself, do his job and head home.

But first impressions can often be deceiving.

In just a few weeks, I heard him speak eloquently in meetings, simplifying complex ideas in a way that everyone understood â€” even new joiners.

I would go on to interact with him and find out how much we had in commonâ€” from table tennis to gym to discussing our same-same taste in cricket and anime. We went from colleagues to buddies in no time.

Professionally, this guy didnâ€™t just do his job â€” he excelled. Divyam was promoted at Google in less than 1.5 years, which for those who know, is basically the top 1% of the top 1%. Calling him a high performer would be an understatement.

On top of that, he helped almost everyone on the team, growing like mad in terms of both programming and soft skills - from small talk to deep tech discussions - I witnessed firsthand how a 10x engineer works.

Now, you might be curious: why did he leave even though he was having a blast of a career at Google?

The answer is simple - having extended the boundaries of what it means to be an engineer so quickly - Divyam realized heâ€™s meant for something bigger (youâ€™d realize the same if you talked to him just once).

With that, I am elated to tell you all that a 10x engineer (whoâ€™s growing more every day) just landed on the market:

- Companies who are looking for top talent in ML - this is your chance, pay whatever it takes to hire him.

- Founders looking for a tech co-founder, this is your shot, pitch him with all you've got.

- VCs looking for a sure bet, this man already has two cool apps out with 10K+ downloads, and is always tinkering. Go chat with him and fund whatever idea he works on next.

You will thank me later if you get him!

---

Divyam, youâ€™re one of the best.

It was nothing short of an honor to have worked and have so much fun â€” outings/meetups/memories outside office with you. And while I plan to annoy you for a long time, not seeing you in office would surely sting.

Youâ€™ll be missed, my friend :')

ğŸ’” 6 Months Without Work â€” But Not Without Hope ğŸ™
I never thought Iâ€™d have to write a post like this â€” but today, Iâ€™m choosing courage over silence, and hope over fear.
With 7 years of experience as a QA Engineer, Iâ€™ve had the privilege to work with top companies like Unacademy, CARS24, CarDekho Group, SCIENTIFIC GAMES, Light & Wonder, and RELIGARE HEALTH INSURANCE (RHI) Health Insurance (now Care Health Insurance).
My domain experience spans across EdTech, Automobile, Health Insurance, and iGaming, giving me a well-rounded view of product and user quality.

I specialize in:
âœ… Manual Testing
âœ… API Testing using Postman
âœ… JIRA, Agile Methodologies
âœ… MySQL Database

Currently, Iâ€™m also upskilling in Automation Testing â€” learning Selenium with Java from Uncodemy, to stay ahead and expand my capabilities.

But for the past 6 months, Iâ€™ve been unemployed, and Iâ€™ll be honest â€” itâ€™s been tough.
Living in Bangalore without a job is not easy, especially as someone who comes from a small village in Bihar, where girls arenâ€™t often encouraged to pursue education.
Being a part of middle-class family background I broke through that barrier, completed my education, and became the first in my family to do so â€” carrying the responsibility of being the eldest daughter and main supporter for my family. My parents always supported me being a farmer and homemaker, now I'm feeling guilty that I'm not capable to support back to them.

Despite the current financial and emotional stress, I havenâ€™t lost hope.
âœ¨ I'm actively looking for a role in:
#QAManual
#ScrumMaster
#AssociateProductManager (APM)

I believe my experience, adaptability, and dedication make me a strong candidate â€” and I am an IMMEDIATE JOINER, ready to contribute from Day 1.
If you or someone you know is hiring, please consider my profile or help me by sharing this post. Even a small action could mean a world of change.
ğŸ“© Feel free to DM me for my resume or any details. Thank you so much for your support!

Letâ€™s remember â€” behind every job title is a person with dreams, struggles, and the will to rise again.

How I Cracked the Goldman Sachs Engineering Campus Hiring Program (EHCP) Aptitude Test

A lot of folks have reached out asking how I prepared for the aptitude test that comes before the Goldman Sachs EHCP interviews.

So hereâ€™s the breakdown:

To reach the interview stage, I first had to clear two rounds of online assessments:
1. Aptitude Test
2. Technical Test

While preparing for the aptitude test, I stumbled upon a goldmine of a YouTube playlist that broke down all the different question patterns in detail.
I focused on mastering the patterns shown in those videosâ€”and honestly, it worked! I was able to solve most of the questions confidently.

YouTube playlist: https://lnkd.in/gkNYSVNR

âš ï¸ Disclaimer:
I took this test in Oct-Nov 2022. The format might have changed since thenâ€”please verify the latest structure before you start preparing.

Hereâ€™s what the format of the Aptitude Test looked like (as of 2022):
â€¢ Total Time: 120 minutes
â€¢ Total Questions: 70
â€¢ Sections: 7 (all mandatory & video proctored)
â€¢ You could switch between sections.

Sections:
â€¢ Numerical Computations â€” 12 Qs
â€¢ Numerical Reasoning â€” 12 Qs
â€¢ Abstract Reasoning â€” 12 Qs
â€¢ Diagrammatic Reasoning â€” 12 Qs
â€¢ Logical Reasoning â€” 12 Qs
â€¢ Comprehension 1 â€” 5 Qs
â€¢ Comprehension 2 â€” 5 Qs

Marking Scheme:
+5 for every correct answer
-2 for every incorrect one

Hope this helps, Iâ€™ll soon share the details of my Technical Test experience.

If I had to start over today and crack a software engineering job as a student, hereâ€™s the roadmap Iâ€™d follow:

â–º Phase 1: Build Your Foundations
1. ğƒğ’ğ€ ğ…ğ¢ğ«ğ¬ğ­ â€“ Start with core topics: Arrays, Strings, Linked Lists, Stacks, Queues
Platforms: GeeksforGeeks, HackerRank, LeetCode (focus on Easy/Medium)
2. ğ‚ğ¨ğ«ğ ğ‚ğ’ ğ’ğ®ğ›ğ£ğğœğ­ğ¬ â€“ Learn in parallel:
â€¢ Operating Systems â€“ Memory management, scheduling, deadlocks
â€¢ DBMS â€“ SQL queries, transactions, indexing
â€¢ Computer Networks â€“ TCP/IP, HTTP, DNS
â€¢ OOPs â€“ Inheritance, polymorphism, design patterns

For a long time, I believed: the more I grind, the better I get.
But then I came across an SDE-3 at Microsoft who cracked it with under 400 problems.
That completely shifted my perspective.

Itâ€™s not about solving 1000+ questions.
Itâ€™s about solving the right ones, recognizing patterns, and building real clarity.

Recently, I discovered Pratik Kapasi (ex-Google coach), who has compiled 127 key patterns that cover almost every tricky FAANG-level question.
Now heâ€™s offering a free 1:1 mentorship call + his Google interview cheat sheet (only 30 spots):
https://lnkd.in/gsqgT7C4

Learn smart. Prepare with direction.
It makes all the difference.

Kuch acha nahi lag raha thaâ€¦

Life se disconnected sa mehsoos kar raha tha.
Jo karna chahta tha, vo sab ho hi nahi raha tha.
Sara din memes dekhta aur banata thaâ€”pehle khush rehta tha, par ab vo bhi maza nahi aa raha tha.

Fir kahin se apne mahaule me Hinglishâ„¢ ki entry hui.
Oho oh oh, oho oh oh oh

Firse khud se connected mehsoos kiya.
Jo bhi andar daba pada tha, sab umad ke nikalne laga.

Phir ek din, Shubham Gune Ustaad ji se mulaqat hui.
Unhone kaha, "Tumse bohot umeed hai mujhe."
Aur bas, samajh aa gaya... mera rasta Hinglishâ„¢ se hai.

I understood the art of crafting.
How words donâ€™t just tell stories, they make people feel them.
How humor and emotions, when blended just right, create an instant connection.

Ab sirf khud ki kahani nahi likhniâ€¦ brands ki bhi likhni hai.

Special thanks to Megha Prasad & Jenil Chavda

Someone, why do you post most of the content in Hindi?

Me: Bhai, this is neither proper Hindi nor proper English; it is Hinglish. (I just feel more comfortable expressing myself in Hinglish.)

What's your take on this??

Does this language thing really matter here?
